articles.title: New discoveries of Australopithecus and Homo from Ledi-Geraru, Ethiopia
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 13 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09390-4Hominin fossils from the Ledi-Geraru Research Project area, Ethiopia, suggest that early Homo and Australopithecus species co-existed in the region more than 2.5 million years ago.
articles.content:
Hominin dental specimens (Fig. 2) were recovered from the three sedimentary packages described above—the Gurumaha, Lee Adoyta, and Giddi Sands (Table 1). Comparative methods and sampling protocols are described in Methods.

Fig. 2: New hominin dentition from the LGRP. Right, from top: LD 302-23 P 3 , LD 750 P 4 , AS 100 M1 and AS 100 M2. Left, images show the LD 760 assemblage (top, from left: maxillary molar, I2, I1, maxillary canine; bottom, mandibular molars). Full size image

Table 1 New Ledi-Geraru hominin dental specimens with geological contexts, ages and identifications Full size table

Gurumaha hominin specimen

A mandibular right third premolar, LD 302-23 (Fig. 2 and Extended Data Fig. 3), was recovered approximately 22 m to the southwest and 7 m stratigraphically below the LD 350 early Homo mandible locality1, above the Gurumaha Tuff17 (Fig. 1b). An enamel fragment is missing from the lingual corner, but the crown is otherwise well preserved. The crown is shorter mesiodistally (MD) than buccolingually (BL) (11.5 mm BL × 10.5 mm MD; Extended Data Fig. 3) and the major crown axis is oriented buccolingually. A relatively small metaconid sits well mesial to the protoconid, creating a tiny, centrally placed anterior fovea that is bounded by a low, but continuous, mesial marginal ridge. Occlusal wear makes it difficult to determine if the metaconid would have been completely distinct from the protoconid at the outer enamel surface. The talonid is mesiodistally short and occupies a relatively small portion of the crown area in occlusal view.

LD 302-23 departs strongly in shape and occlusal form from P 3 s attributed to Australopithecus anamensis and Australopithecus deyiremeda, and unicuspid specimens of A. afarensis (for example, A.L. 128-23 and A.L. 288-1), in which the major axis of an asymmetric crown runs mesiobuccal to distolingual and in having a continuous mesial marginal ridge that creates a ‘closed’ anterior fovea7,21,22 (Extended Data Fig. 3a). Some A. afarensis specimens (such as A.L. 437-2) resemble the crown outline of LD 302-23 (Extended Data Fig. 3a); however, LD 302-23 also differs from those specimens in having a mesially shifted metaconid, which creates an acute angle between the transverse crest and mesial protoconid crest, and in having a highly reduced anterior fovea relative to crown size23. In crown shape index (MD/BL), LD 302-23 falls in the middle range of the A. afarensis distribution (Extended Data Fig. 3b,c). In area (BL × MD), LD 302-23 falls within the range of the A. afarensis size distribution, at the lower limit of the range of Paranthropus boisei, but within the range of values of Paranthropus robustus (Extended Data Fig. 3b,d). Unlike Paranthropus12, the talonid of LD 302-23 is not expansive. We attribute LD 302-23 to Homo for a number of reasons. Although the sample of P 3 s attributed to early Homo is morphologically diverse (for example, KNM-ER 5431, OMO 75-14, KNM-ER 1802 and OH 7), LD 302-23 is clearly derived relative to pre-3.0 Ma Australopithecus, lacks the suite of derived nonmetric features characteristic of Paranthropus, and is consistent with the size, crown morphology and mesiodistal compression of the LD 350-1 specimen (the LD 350-1 P 3 crown is damaged mesiolingually, with only around 65% of the crown remaining), which was found in the same sedimentary package and shares numerous dental and mandibular apomorphies with Homo.

Lee Adoyta hominin specimens

An isolated P 4 , LD 750-115670 (Fig. 2, Extended Data Fig. 4 and Supplementary Fig. 4), was collected from locality LD 750 at the base of an approximately 8-m-thick fossiliferous exposure of mudstone and sandstone. The stratigraphic position of the locality lies between the 2.63 Ma LAT and the 2.59 Ma GST (Fig. 1b and Extended Data Fig. 2a). The LD 750 P 4 is unworn, with salient mesial cusps (Extended Data Fig. 4a). The roots are broken beneath the crown, but the mesial portion preserves a maximum root height of about 2.0 mm. The tooth may not have been fully erupted, as there are no interproximal contact facets and the occlusal surface is unworn. The protoconid and metaconid are shifted relatively mesially on the crown and tightly compressed BL, giving the tooth a slightly ‘puffy’ appearance. The anterior fovea is distinct and deep, but relatively small (reflecting the mesial placement of the cusps), centrally placed and bounded by a narrow mesial marginal ridge. The talonid is relatively large, the distal marginal ridge is low and rounded, and a distinct, but low, distolingual cusp is present, giving the tooth an asymmetric occlusal profile.

With dimensions of 12.4 mm BL × 11.4 mm MD, the tooth area is in the upper size range of A. afarensis, exceeded in area only by A.L. 996-1 (Extended Data Fig. 4b). Morphologically, however, the LD 750 P 4 departs from the typical Hadar A. afarensis appearance. For example, the lingual to mesial face transition is smooth and rounded, whereas in Hadar P 4 s there is a more distinct corner. The occlusal layout differs from that of Hadar P 4 s in that the metaconid and protoconid are placed more centrally in relation to buccolingual crown breadth and shifted mesially in relation to crown length. Thus, compared with Hadar A. afarensis teeth, the buccal face is more convex occlusocervically and the anterior fovea more confined. The index of protoconid–metaconid apex distance/BL breadth shows the central placement of the LD 750 mesial cusp apices in relation to crown breadth compared with A. afarensis (Extended Data Fig. 4c,d).

Not only is LD 750 large relative to most A. afarensis specimens, it also exceeds the area of all specimens attributed to A. anamensis and all but two specimens of Australopithecus africanus (StW 498 and StW 384). The LD 750 crown area falls within the size distribution of P. robustus and Paranthropus aethiopicus; however, it lacks any of the distinct ‘molarization’ seen in Paranthropus P 4 s (for example, expanded talonid and distal cusps, thick marginal ridges, symmetrically rounded occlusal profile caused by the filling of the crown distobuccally, and surface complexity in unworn specimens12). We note that the known specimen of A. garhi lacks any mandibular remains3, but LD 750 cannot be excluded from that species on the basis of size alone (see randomization analysis in Extended Data Fig. 4e). In occlusal form and crown outline, LD 750 does resemble OMO 75-14 (Extended Data Fig. 4a), which has been attributed to aff. Homo by Suwa et al.12 and Hlusko et al.24, and KNM-ER 5431, which is also attributed to Homo by Suwa et al.12. However, these attributions are provisional and based mostly on the nonmetric morphology of their associated molars (for example, presence of C7 on M 1 and M 2 of both specimens). In fact, P 4 morphology poorly distinguishes between early Homo and Australopithecus12,24. Thus, the phenetic resemblance between OMO 75-14, KNM-ER 5431 and LD 750, which are all large but lack features typical of Paranthropus, could be most parsimoniously interpreted as symplesiomorphic retentions. Since LD 750-115670 lacks any clear Homo synapomorphies associated with other specimens of early Homo from Koobi Fora (such as talonid reduction in KNM-ER 99225), we provisionally assign it to aff. Australopithecus.

An associated set of five mandibular molars, a maxillary molar fragment, and three maxillary anterior teeth (Fig. 2 and Table 1) representing a single individual were collected at locality LD 760, a relatively flat-lying area dominated by fine-grained sand and silts (Supplementary Video 1). The hominin teeth were all found in close association, in a relatively dense cluster among scattered faunal elements (Extended Data Fig. 2b). The mandibular molars were found eroding from the surface and the maxillary dentition was sieved from the surface silt (approximately 5–10 cm of loose and eroded surface soil) downslope on a gentle gradient over a 7 × 4 m area to the northwest. The LD 760 collection area lies approximately 10 m below the 2.631 ± 0.011 Ma LAT17 mapped in hillslopes surrounding the site (Fig. 1a and Extended Data Fig. 2a,b). Mammalian fossils were also observed eroding from sand units around 3.5 m and 6.5 m above the LAT (Fig. 1b). However, on the basis of the slope and distance to these sand units, as well as the abundance and spread of other fossil specimens, the hominin teeth and other fossils on the LD 760 surface represent a distinct fossiliferous unit below the LAT.

The LD 760 mandibular molars are moderately worn, with dentine exposure visible at buccal cusp apices in the M 1 (Fig. 3). They are relatively wide BL compared to their MD length (Extended Data Figs. 5 and 6) and do not taper strongly distally, which gives the crowns, especially M 1 and M 2 , a squarish profile (Fig. 4). The buccal grooves are indistinct, and the buccal profile is convex in occlusal view, in part because a protostylid partially fills in the buccal groove. Further, the buccal crown face slopes occlusocervically, reflecting an internal placement of cusp apices.

Fig. 3: LD 760 molars compared to A. afarensis. Left molars from Ledi-Geraru specimen LD 760 (left) and Hadar specimen A.L. 400-1 (right). Measurements in mm of the LD 760 molars (BL × MD): LM 1 : 13.3 × 13.4, LM 2 : 14.5 × 14.6, LM 3 : 14.0 (estimated) × 15.7, RM 1 : 13.2 × 13.1, RM 2 : 14.8 × 15.2 (Supplementary Data 1). Specimens are oriented with their buccal surfaces to the left and mesial surfaces up. Full size image

Fig. 4: Contour of LD 760 compared to A. afarensis. Detail of distal taper (orange lines) and bilobate contour (blue lines) seen in A. afarensis M 1 specimen A.L. 400-1 (right) contrasted with the overall more equilateral occlusal profile of the LD 760 M 1 (left). The M 2 s also show this pattern (Fig. 3). Specimens are oriented with their buccal surfaces to the left and mesial surfaces up. Full size image

There is no hint of M 3 reduction (as seen, for example, in some early Homo such as LD 350-1 and OMO-75-14); instead, the molars follow the plesiomorphic pattern of relative molar size, M 1 < M 2 < M 3 . The M 1 and M 2 are subequally square (Extended Data Figs. 5 and 6), unlike in early Homo which tend to have rectangular crowns that are mesiodistally elongated. Further, the teeth are relatively simple, with few accessory cusps; the M 1 s show no expression of a C7, unlike LD 350-1 and KNM-ER 1802, and the M 2 s also lack a C7, which is seen in many specimens attributed to early Homo (for example, OMO-75-14, KNM-ER 5431, KNM-ER 60000 and OH 7). The mesiodistal dimensions of the mandibular molars comfortably fit within the metric variation seen in individual A. afarensis molars (Extended Data Fig. 5), and the buccolingual breadths fall in the upper third of the A. afarensis distribution. However, the sum of the molar areas for the LD 760 individual (614.3 mm2) exceeds all but one (NFR-VP-1/29; Woranso-Mille, Afar Region, Ethiopia) of the 11 A. afarensis individuals that preserve all 3 molars; yet, among Paranthropus, only 1 individual (DNH 7) is smaller in M 1 –M 3 area than LD 760 (Extended Data Fig. 5d). The LD 760 molars depart from the typical feature set of A. afarensis in three ways: (1) the M 1 s are buccolingually broad relative to their mesiodistsal length (A. afarensis M 1 s and M 2 s are buccolingually widest across the mesial cusps, the LD 760 M 1 is equally wide at midcrown and the M 2 is only slightly narrower at midcrown) (Extended Data Figs. 5 and 6); (2) the M 1 and M 2 do not taper distally to the extent seen in A. afarensis (Figs. 3 and 4); and (3) the LD 760 molars lack the distinct bilobate buccal contour seen in A. afarensis12 (Fig. 4).

A fragmentary maxillary molar, LD 760-115911, was recovered at the LD 760 locality (Extended Data Fig. 7a). Although the protocone is the only fully preserved cusp, the lingual groove is distinct occlusally and the mesial edge of the hypocone is present. On A. garhi upper molars, the lingual groove is indistinct, but the lingual margin of the crown begins to curve buccally distal to the lingual groove, reflecting the relatively small hypocone and buccolingually narrow distal crown (Extended Data Fig. 7a). This reduction in hypocone area produces a triangular form for the Bouri specimen’s protocone. The LD 760 upper molar fragment shows no similar curvature of the crown margin distal to the lingual groove. Instead, it appears to have had a fully expressed hypocone. However, in terms of absolute molar area (BL × MD), the ratio of LD 760 lower molars to the A. garhi upper molars does not falsify a single-species hypothesis using modern ape comparative data—see resampling analysis in Extended Data Fig. 6b.

A right maxillary canine, a complete left maxillary lateral incisor and a left fragmentary maxillary central incisor were also found at the LD 760 locality (Fig. 2 and Table 1). The canine (LD 760-115979) is well preserved, with all but the root apex present (Fig. 5). The crown has mesial and distal interproximal contact facets. A distal interproximal contact facet is also present on the LI2, which indicates bilateral absence of a canine/I2 diastema; a diastema is present on the BOU-VP-12/130 A. garhi maxilla and is variably present in A. afarensis. The canine crown is worn apically and along the mesial and distal crests. Apical wear makes it difficult to examine the relative placement of the crown shoulders, but the mesial shoulder appears to have been placed apically. Despite the wear, the canine is not small (Extended Data Fig. 8a–c), and the ratio of the canine to molar mesiodistal dimensions puts this specimen in the upper range of Australopithecus and well beyond the observed values for Paranthropus (Extended Data Fig. 8d).

Fig. 5: Comparative maxillary canine morphology. a, Lingual (left) and labial (right) views of the Ledi-Geraru LD 760-115979 canine (left) with Hadar A. afarensis specimens A.L. 763-1 (middle) and A.L. 333x-3 (right). Note that the LD 760 canine is a right canine, whereas the A. afarensis canines are from the left and are mirrored in these images. b–d, LD 760-115979 (b; shown in lingual view) contrasted with Hadar A. afarensis specimen A.L. 199-1 (c; right canine shown; distal to the upper right) and Bouri A. garhi specimen BOU-VP-12/130 (d; left canine, mirrored; distal is to the right). Note the simple mesial–distal chisel-like wear pattern on the LD 760 canine (b) in contrast to the complex multi-faceted wear pattern of A. afarensis (c) and the broad curved basin on the distal side of the A. garhi upper canine (d; this is seen on both left and right canines). Images are oriented differently to emphasize the distinctive relevant morphology. Photos of BOU-VP-12/130 A. garhi holotype fossil by T. White; use courtesy of the Middle Awash research project. Images in b–d are not to scale. Full size image

The LD 760 canine departs subtly from the macrowear of A. afarensis (Fig. 5). For example, its wear pattern lacks the characteristic ‘j-pattern’ along the distal crest26; instead, apical wear dominates. In basal size (10.4 mm BL × 10.5 mm MD) the tooth resembles A. afarensis and is narrower than the labio-lingually broad canine of A. garhi (Extended Data Fig. 9). The LD 760 canine also departs morphologically from A. garhi. The A. garhi canine, uniquely among hominins, possesses a broad, shallow distal basin reminiscent of a talon (Fig. 5d); this smooth basin is contiguous with a wide wear furrow that characterizes the entire postcanine dental row (Extended Data Fig. 9a).

The LD 760 individual cannot be attributed to Paranthropus. It lacks the derived reduction of anterior tooth size, which is reflected both in the absolute sizes of the anterior teeth and their size relative to the postcanine dentition (Extended Data Fig. 8d). The mandibular molars do not express relatively large C6s12 and they show a buccolingual wear gradient distinct from the planar pattern typical of Paranthropus12. The LD 760 teeth also lack any derived Homo traits (such as steeply walled molars, narrow M 1 , C7 presence and M 3 reduction). We regard the morphology of LD 760 as inconsistent with known eastern African Australopithecus species because: (1) the lack of any of the derived A. garhi traits, notably the reduced hypocone of the maxillary molars and highly distinctive upper canine ‘talon’ basin; and (2) a morphology derived relative to A. afarensis (that is, lack of bilobate mandibular molar walls and distal taper, and canine wear pattern). Because of the plesiomorphic resemblance to A. afarensis, we make a generic-level attribution and assign the LD 760 assemblage to Australopithecus sp. indet.

Giddi Sands hominin specimens

A partial left M1 crown with lingual cusps only partially preserved (AS 100-1a) and 2 fragments assembled into a complete left M2 crown (AS 100-1b) were discovered eroded from the approximately 1-m-thick Giddi Sands unit in the Asboli region immediately below the GST (Fig. 2, Table 1 and Supplementary Fig. 5). Subsequent screening produced no additional hominin material.

Wear on these teeth is slight, with crown apices salient and no dentine exposed. Interstitial wear is present and the interproximal contact facets are congruent, consistent with identification of AS 100-1a as an M1 and AS 100-1b as an M2 (Fig. 2 and Extended Data Fig. 7). The AS 100-1b M2 is rhomboidal in occlusal outline, with the cusps offset such that the buccal pair sits mesial to the lingual pair, the hypocone is relatively large and projects distolingually, and the lingual profile is straight. A. afarensis M2s range in shape from squarish (for example, A.L. 199-1, A.L. 486-1) to more rhomboidal (for example, A.L. 444-2, A.L. 200-1)27, but A. afarensis specimens invariably show more pronounced lingual occlusocervical sloping, indicating a more internally placed cuspal arrangement than is apparent for AS 100-1b. The lingual cusps of the AS 100 molars are relatively steep vertically and lack the ‘puffy’ contour seen in relatively unworn specimens of A. afarensis (for example, A.L. 200-1). The rhomboidal crown outline, relatively large and projecting hypocone, and cuspal placement of AS 100-1b are closely matched by A.L. 666-1, a Homo specimen from the Busidima Formation at Hadar28 from 2.3 Ma, and MLP-1549, a Homo specimen from Mille-Logya29, 2.5–2.4 Ma. This feature set strongly contrasts with the A. garhi M2 in which the hypocone is relatively small and placed transverse to the metacone, the lingual profile is strongly curved, and the cusps are more internally placed (Extended Data Fig. 7a). In size, the AS 100-1b M2 (14.2 mm BL × 13.9 mm MD) and Homo specimen A.L. 666-1 are nearly identical and both slightly exceed the Mille-Logya M2 in BL breadth; AS 100-1b is smaller in area than the M2 of A. garhi and eastern African Paranthropus (Extended Data Fig. 7b). We attribute AS 100-1 to Homo sp. indet. based on the presence of a derived M2 crown outline (that is, rhomboidal with projecting relatively large hypocone30), a feature shared with other specimens of early Homo.

articles.personality_title: New fossil finds show early humans and relatives lived together in Ethiopia 2.5 million years ago
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists study ancient fossils to learn about human origins. Ethiopia is a key place where early human ancestors lived millions of years ago. Fossils help us understand how species like Australopithecus and early Homo evolved.

**What happened** – Researchers discovered new teeth and jaw fossils from two ancient species, Australopithecus and early Homo, in the Ledi-Geraru area of Ethiopia. These fossils are over 2.5 million years old. They found different teeth from several individuals buried in layers of sediment called Gurumaha, Lee Adoyta, and Giddi Sands. The fossils show features that connect them to both Australopithecus and early Homo species.

**Impact** – These discoveries are important because they show that early Homo and Australopithecus lived in the same region at the same time. This means the two groups co-existed more than 2.5 million years ago. The fossils also have unique dental shapes that help scientists understand differences and similarities between these early species. This adds new information about how human ancestors evolved and interacted.

**What's next step** – Scientists will continue studying these fossils and search for more in Ethiopia. Comparing these finds with fossils from other sites can clarify the timeline of human evolution. This research may help identify new species or better explain how early humans developed traits like bigger brains and smaller teeth.

**One-sentence takeaway** – New fossil teeth from Ethiopia reveal that early Homo and Australopithecus species lived together over 2.5 million years ago, offering fresh clues about human evolution.
articles.personality_title_fr: De nouvelles fossiles montrent que les premiers humains et leurs proches vivaient ensemble en Éthiopie il y a 2,5 millions d’années
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques étudient les fossiles anciens pour mieux comprendre les origines humaines. L’Éthiopie est un lieu clé où vivaient les ancêtres humains il y a des millions d’années. Les fossiles aident à comprendre l’évolution des espèces comme Australopithecus et les premiers Homo.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs ont découvert de nouvelles dents et mâchoires d’Australopithecus et de premiers Homo dans la région de Ledi-Geraru en Éthiopie. Ces fossiles ont plus de 2,5 millions d’années. Ils ont trouvé des dents appartenant à plusieurs individus dans différentes couches de sédiments appelées Gurumaha, Lee Adoyta et Giddi Sands. Les fossiles montrent des caractéristiques liées à ces deux groupes.

**Impact** – Ces découvertes sont importantes car elles prouvent que les premiers Homo et les Australopithecus ont vécu ensemble dans la même région il y a plus de 2,5 millions d’années. Les formes uniques des dents aident aussi les scientifiques à comprendre les différences et similitudes entre ces espèces anciennes. Cela enrichit nos connaissances sur l’évolution et les interactions des ancêtres humains.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques vont continuer à étudier ces fossiles et chercher d’autres découvertes en Éthiopie. En comparant ces fossiles avec ceux d’autres sites, ils pourront mieux comprendre la chronologie de l’évolution humaine. Cette recherche pourrait permettre d’identifier de nouvelles espèces ou d’expliquer comment les traits humains ont évolué.

**Phrase clé** – De nouvelles dents fossiles d’Éthiopie montrent que les premiers Homo et Australopithecus ont vécu ensemble il y a plus de 2,5 millions d’années, apportant de nouveaux indices sur l’évolution humaine.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevos fósiles muestran que los primeros humanos y sus parientes vivieron juntos en Etiopía hace 2,5 millones de años
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos estudian fósiles antiguos para entender mejor los orígenes humanos. Etiopía es un lugar importante donde vivieron los antepasados humanos hace millones de años. Los fósiles ayudan a comprender cómo evolucionaron especies como Australopithecus y los primeros Homo.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores encontraron nuevos dientes y mandíbulas de Australopithecus y primeros Homo en la zona de Ledi-Geraru, Etiopía. Estos fósiles tienen más de 2,5 millones de años. Se hallaron dientes de varios individuos en diferentes capas de sedimentos llamadas Gurumaha, Lee Adoyta y Giddi Sands. Los fósiles muestran características que los conectan con ambos grupos.

**Impacto** – Estos hallazgos son importantes porque muestran que los primeros Homo y Australopithecus convivieron en la misma región hace más de 2,5 millones de años. Las formas especiales de los dientes ayudan a los científicos a entender las diferencias y similitudes entre estas especies antiguas. Esto aporta nueva información sobre cómo evolucionaron e interactuaron los antepasados humanos.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos seguirán estudiando estos fósiles y buscando más en Etiopía. Al comparar estos hallazgos con fósiles de otros lugares, podrán aclarar mejor la línea del tiempo de la evolución humana. Esta investigación podría ayudar a identificar nuevas especies o explicar cómo se desarrollaron rasgos humanos.

**Frase clave** – Nuevos dientes fósiles de Etiopía revelan que primeros Homo y Australopithecus vivieron juntos hace más de 2,5 millones de años, ofreciendo nuevas pistas sobre la evolución humana.

articles.title: NASA Glenn Shoots for the Stars During WNBA All-Star Weekend
articles.summary: From astronauts to athletes, researchers to referees, and communicators to coaches, NASA is much like basketball – we all train to reach the top of our game. Staff from NASA’s Glenn Research Center in Cleveland drove home this point during the “All-Star Shoot for the Stars” event at The Children’s Museum of Indianapolis, July 17-19. […]
articles.content:
Astronaut Victor Glover interacts with an Orion spacecraft simulator during NASA’s “All-Star Shoot for the Stars” event at The Children’s Museum of Indianapolis on Saturday, July 18, 2025. Credit: NASA/Zach Lucas

From astronauts to athletes, researchers to referees, and communicators to coaches, NASA is much like basketball – we all train to reach the top of our game. Staff from NASA’s Glenn Research Center in Cleveland drove home this point during the “All-Star Shoot for the Stars” event at The Children’s Museum of Indianapolis, July 17-19. As part of WNBA All-Star Game activities, this event highlighted NASA technology while illuminating the intersection of sports and STEM.

The event offered a captivating look into space exploration, thanks to the combined efforts of NASA and museum staff. Highlights included a detailed Orion exhibit, a new spacesuit display featuring five full-scale spacesuits, and virtual reality demonstrations. Visitors also had the chance to enjoy an interactive spacesuit app and a unique cosmic selfie station.

On Friday, July 18, 2025, visitors at NASA’s “All-Star Shoot for the Stars” event at The Children’s Museum of Indianapolis look at a new spacesuit display featuring five full-scale spacesuits. Credit: NASA/Christopher Richards

The event was made even more memorable by Artemis II astronaut Victor Glover, who connected with visitors and posed for photos. WNBA legend Tamika Catchings also made a special appearance, inspiring attendees with a message to “aim high!”

“All Star Weekend presented an excellent opportunity to share NASA’s mission with the Indianapolis community and people across the Midwest who were in town for the game,” said Jan Wittry, Glenn’s news chief. “I saw children’s faces light up as they interacted with the exhibits and talked to NASA experts, sparking a curiosity among our potential future STEM workforce.”
articles.reasoning: The article describes a NASA outreach event that successfully inspires public interest in STEM and space exploration by engaging a broad community audience, including children, through interactive exhibits and appearances by astronauts and athletes. This has a positive real-world impact by encouraging STEM education and curiosity among the general public, with clear context and meaningful engagement.
articles.personality_title: NASA Inspires Kids with Space and Sports at WNBA All-Star Event
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – NASA’s Glenn Research Center joined the WNBA All-Star Weekend in Indianapolis to connect space exploration with sports and STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math) education.

**What happened** – From July 17 to 19, 2025, NASA held the “All-Star Shoot for the Stars” event at The Children’s Museum of Indianapolis. Visitors explored an Orion spacecraft exhibit, saw five full-size spacesuits, tried virtual reality experiences, and used an interactive spacesuit app. Artemis II astronaut Victor Glover and basketball star Tamika Catchings made special appearances to meet guests and encourage them to aim high.

**Impact** – The event blended sports and space to make learning about NASA’s work exciting and fun. Children and families got hands-on experiences and met real astronauts and athletes, which helped spark interest in STEM fields. This kind of outreach helps inspire the next generation of scientists, engineers, and explorers.

**What’s next step** – NASA plans to continue similar events that bring space science to public places, especially where young people can engage directly. These efforts aim to keep growing curiosity and support for STEM education across the country.

**One-sentence takeaway** – NASA’s interactive exhibits and star guests at the WNBA All-Star Weekend inspired children to explore space and STEM through the excitement of sports.
articles.personality_title_fr: La NASA inspire les enfants avec l’espace et le sport lors du WNBA All-Star
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le centre de recherche Glenn de la NASA a participé au week-end All-Star de la WNBA à Indianapolis pour relier l’exploration spatiale au sport et à l’éducation STEM (science, technologie, ingénierie et mathématiques).

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Du 17 au 19 juillet 2025, la NASA a organisé l’événement « All-Star Shoot for the Stars » au Musée des Enfants d’Indianapolis. Les visiteurs ont découvert une exposition sur le vaisseau Orion, vu cinq combinaisons spatiales grandeur nature, essayé la réalité virtuelle et utilisé une application interactive sur les combinaisons spatiales. L’astronaute Artemis II Victor Glover et la star du basketball Tamika Catchings sont venus rencontrer le public et encourager les visiteurs à viser haut.

**Impact** – L’événement a mêlé sport et espace pour rendre l’apprentissage de la NASA amusant et passionnant. Les enfants et les familles ont pu vivre des expériences pratiques et rencontrer de vrais astronautes et athlètes, ce qui a aidé à susciter l’intérêt pour les domaines STEM. Ce type d’initiative aide à inspirer la prochaine génération de scientifiques, ingénieurs et explorateurs.

**Prochaine étape** – La NASA prévoit de continuer à organiser des événements similaires dans des lieux publics, surtout là où les jeunes peuvent s’engager directement. Ces actions visent à développer la curiosité et le soutien à l’éducation STEM à travers le pays.

**Phrase clé** – Les expositions interactives de la NASA et ses invités stars lors du WNBA All-Star Weekend ont inspiré les enfants à découvrir l’espace et les STEM grâce à l’excitation du sport.
articles.personality_title_es: La NASA inspira a niños con espacio y deportes en el WNBA All-Star
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El Centro de Investigación Glenn de la NASA participó en el fin de semana All-Star de la WNBA en Indianápolis para conectar la exploración espacial con el deporte y la educación STEM (ciencia, tecnología, ingeniería y matemáticas).

**Qué pasó** – Del 17 al 19 de julio de 2025, la NASA organizó el evento “All-Star Shoot for the Stars” en el Museo de los Niños de Indianápolis. Los visitantes exploraron una exhibición de la nave Orion, vieron cinco trajes espaciales a tamaño real, probaron experiencias de realidad virtual y usaron una aplicación interactiva sobre los trajes espaciales. El astronauta Artemis II Victor Glover y la estrella del baloncesto Tamika Catchings hicieron apariciones especiales para conocer a los asistentes y animarlos a apuntar alto.

**Impacto** – El evento combinó el deporte y el espacio para hacer que aprender sobre la NASA fuera divertido y emocionante. Niños y familias tuvieron experiencias prácticas y conocieron astronautas y atletas reales, lo que ayudó a despertar interés en las áreas STEM. Este tipo de actividades ayuda a inspirar a la próxima generación de científicos, ingenieros y exploradores.

**Próximo paso** – La NASA planea continuar con eventos similares que lleven la ciencia espacial a lugares públicos, especialmente donde los jóvenes puedan participar directamente. Estos esfuerzos buscan aumentar la curiosidad y el apoyo a la educación STEM en todo el país.

**Frase clave** – Las exhibiciones interactivas de la NASA y sus invitados especiales en el WNBA All-Star Weekend inspiraron a los niños a explorar el espacio y STEM a través de la emoción del deporte.

articles.title: DNA analysis reveals West African ancestry in early medieval England
articles.summary: An unrelated pair of people buried in cemeteries in 7th-century Britain probably had grandparents from West Africa
articles.content:
An unrelated pair of people buried in cemeteries in 7th-century Britain probably had grandparents from West Africa

The skeleton of a girl from Updown cemetary, who was found to have West African ancestry M George et al.

Two unrelated young people buried in cemeteries in England in the Early Middle Ages probably had grandparents from West Africa. How and when their relatives arrived in Britain is unknown, but the discovery implies that migrants in Anglo-Saxon times were coming from much further afield than previously thought.

After the Romans finally withdrew from Britain in AD 410, Britain was invaded and settled by Germanic Angles, Saxons and Jutes. To investigate whether people also arrived from elsewhere, Duncan Sayer at the University of Central Lancashire, UK, and his colleagues have analysed ancient DNA from the bones of people buried in two 7th-century cemeteries on England’s southern coast.

One of them is in Updown in Kent, where many traded objects from around the world have been found, including pots, buckles and brooches from Frankish Gaul, and garnets in jewellery that may have come from India. The people in the cemetery were often buried with items like cookware, cutlery or combs.

The other cemetery is in Worth Matravers, Dorset, further west. The people there are buried in a Romano-British manner, with few grave goods.

The majority of those in the cemeteries had, as expected, either northern European or western British and Irish ancestry, but a girl at Updown and a young man at Worth Matravers had a recent ancestor, likely a grandparent, from West Africa.

Subscriber-only newsletter Sign up to Our Human Story Each month, Michael Marshall unearths the latest news and ideas about ancient humans, evolution, archaeology and more. Sign up to newsletter

In both cases, the mitochondrial DNA, which is passed down from the mother, was northern European, but the autosomal DNA, which comes from both parents equally, had 20 to 40 per cent ancestry akin to that of the present-day Yoruba, Mende, Mandinka and Esan groups from sub-Saharan West Africa.

This means the West African DNA probably comes from a grandfather – and it is the first evidence for genetic connections between Britain and Africa during the Early Middle Ages.

Both young people were buried as typical members of the community. The DNA analysis also showed that two relatives of “Updown Girl”, who was about 11 to 13 years old when she died, are in the same cemetery: a grandmother and an aunt.

Looking at the ratios of isotopes of carbon and nitrogen in a bone sample from the Worth Matravers youth, who was aged between 17 and 25 when he died, showed what he had eaten when the bones were forming.

“From his diet, it looks like he was born and raised in England,” says team member Ceiridwen Edwards at the University of Huddersfield, UK.

There is evidence for African DNA in York in the Roman period, says Edwards. However, Sayer thinks the proportion of West African DNA in the youngsters in the cemeteries would be far lower if they were descendants of people from the days of Roman rule. “This is a grandparent, so it’s definitely not about surviving Roman military or administrators, which were several hundred years in the past,” he says.

There is also no evidence to suggest that these people were slaves, says Sayer: “These individuals are being buried as fully fledged members of their community.”

Instead, he suggests, this is to do with trading and the movement of goods and people. At some point, people from West Africa had come to Britain, perhaps on a trading ship, and stayed.

Sayer thinks their arrival may have been linked to the reconquest of North Africa by the Byzantine Empire, also known as the Eastern Roman Empire, in the 6th century. That military action was taken to get access to gold from sub-Saharan Africa. “The reopening of this channel is taking place at a time that would correspond very much with the grandparents of these two people,” he says.

“This work exemplifies how dynamic the post-[Western] Roman and early medieval periods were in Britain,” says Marina Soares Da Silva at the Francis Crick Institute in London. “The authors propose trading routes facilitated by the Byzantine Empire rule in North Africa, and I think that’s a valid possibility.”

Seventh-century England was certainly no “dark age” collection of small, rural, isolated communities, says Sayer. “These are dynamic communities with artefacts being traded, and gene flow taking place, all the way from West Africa and beyond.”
articles.reasoning: The article reveals a significant historical discovery showing genetic connections between early medieval England and West Africa, highlighting dynamic cultural and genetic exchanges in the past. This broadens understanding of migration and diversity in history, providing meaningful insight into human ancestry and challenging previous assumptions about early medieval Britain. The story has broad educational and cultural significance with clear context and evidence.
articles.personality_title: DNA shows West African roots in 7th-century England
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – After the Romans left Britain around AD 410, the island was mainly settled by groups from northern Europe, like the Angles and Saxons. Until now, people thought migration to Britain in the Early Middle Ages mostly came from nearby regions.

**What happened** – Scientists studied ancient DNA from two cemeteries in southern England dated to the 7th century. They found that a young girl buried in Kent and a young man buried in Dorset each had a grandparent from West Africa. Their DNA showed a mix of European and West African ancestry, which was surprising for that time and place.

**Impact** – This is the first clear genetic proof that people with West African ancestry lived in England during the Early Middle Ages. It shows that Britain was connected to faraway places through trade and movement of people, not just nearby Europe. The young man’s diet also suggested he grew up in England, meaning his family had settled there.

**What’s next step** – Researchers want to learn more about how and when people from West Africa reached Britain. They will study other ancient sites and look for more evidence of early global connections. This could change how we understand migration and cultural exchange in history.

**One-sentence takeaway** – DNA from 7th-century cemeteries reveals that people with West African ancestors lived in England, showing early medieval Britain was more connected to the wider world than previously known.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'ADN révèle des racines ouest-africaines dans l'Angleterre du VIIe siècle
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Après le départ des Romains vers 410 après J.-C., la Grande-Bretagne a été principalement peuplée par des groupes venus d'Europe du Nord, comme les Angles et les Saxons. Jusqu'à présent, on pensait que les migrations vers la Grande-Bretagne au début du Moyen Âge venaient surtout des régions proches.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des scientifiques ont étudié l'ADN ancien de deux cimetières dans le sud de l'Angleterre datant du VIIe siècle. Ils ont découvert qu'une jeune fille enterrée dans le Kent et un jeune homme enterré dans le Dorset avaient chacun un grand-parent originaire d'Afrique de l'Ouest. Leur ADN montrait un mélange d'ascendance européenne et ouest-africaine, ce qui était surprenant pour cette époque et ce lieu.

**Impact** – C'est la première preuve génétique claire que des personnes avec des ancêtres ouest-africains vivaient en Angleterre au début du Moyen Âge. Cela montre que la Grande-Bretagne était reliée à des endroits lointains par le commerce et les mouvements de population, pas seulement à l'Europe proche. Le régime alimentaire du jeune homme suggérait aussi qu'il avait grandi en Angleterre, ce qui signifie que sa famille s'était installée là.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs veulent en savoir plus sur la façon et le moment où des personnes d'Afrique de l'Ouest sont arrivées en Grande-Bretagne. Ils étudieront d'autres sites anciens et chercheront plus de preuves de connexions mondiales précoces. Cela pourrait changer notre compréhension des migrations et des échanges culturels dans l'histoire.

**Une phrase clé** – L'ADN de cimetières du VIIe siècle révèle que des personnes avec des ancêtres ouest-africains vivaient en Angleterre, montrant que le début du Moyen Âge britannique était plus connecté au monde que ce qu'on pensait.
articles.personality_title_es: El ADN muestra raíces de África Occidental en la Inglaterra del siglo VII
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Tras la retirada de los romanos alrededor del año 410 d.C., Gran Bretaña fue principalmente habitada por grupos del norte de Europa, como los anglosajones. Hasta ahora se pensaba que la migración a Gran Bretaña en la Edad Media temprana venía sobre todo de regiones cercanas.

**Qué pasó** – Científicos estudiaron ADN antiguo de dos cementerios en el sur de Inglaterra del siglo VII. Encontraron que una niña enterrada en Kent y un joven en Dorset tenían cada uno un abuelo de África Occidental. Su ADN mostraba una mezcla de ascendencia europea y africana occidental, algo inesperado para esa época y lugar.

**Impacto** – Esta es la primera prueba genética clara de que personas con ancestros de África Occidental vivieron en Inglaterra durante la Edad Media temprana. Esto demuestra que Gran Bretaña estaba conectada con lugares lejanos a través del comercio y el movimiento de personas, no solo con Europa cercana. La dieta del joven también indica que creció en Inglaterra, lo que significa que su familia se había establecido allí.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores quieren saber más sobre cómo y cuándo llegaron personas de África Occidental a Gran Bretaña. Estudiarán otros sitios antiguos y buscarán más evidencia de conexiones globales tempranas. Esto podría cambiar nuestra comprensión de la migración y el intercambio cultural en la historia.

**Una frase clave** – El ADN de cementerios del siglo VII revela que personas con ancestros de África Occidental vivieron en Inglaterra, mostrando que la Gran Bretaña medieval temprana estaba más conectada con el mundo de lo que se pensaba.

articles.title: Global study reveals the surprising habit behind tough decisions
articles.summary: A sweeping international study has revealed that when faced with complex decisions, people across cultures—from bustling megacities to remote Amazon communities—tend to rely on their own judgment rather than seeking advice. The research, spanning over 3,500 participants in 12 countries, challenges the long-held belief that self-reliance is primarily a Western trait. While cultural values influence how strongly individuals lean on their inner voice, the preference for private reflection remains a shared human tendency.
articles.content:
An international study surveying people in a dozen countries found that when it comes to making complex decisions, people all over the world tend to reflect on their own, rather than seek advice.

Researchers from the University of Waterloo led the new study that surveyed more than 3,500 people from megacities to small Indigenous communities in the Amazon rainforest to learn how they make decisions. This work is the broadest test of decision-style preferences across cultures to date.

The researchers say that by understanding that even in interdependent societies most people prefer to go with the decision made by themselves, irrespective of what others say, can help clarify cross-cultural misunderstandings and realize that we all appear to be juggling similar internal debates.

"Realizing that most of us instinctively 'go it alone' helps explain why we often ignore good counsel, be it for health tips or financial planning, despite mounting evidence that such counsel may help us make wiser decisions," said Dr. Igor Grossmann, professor in the Department of Psychology at Waterloo and first author on the paper. "This knowledge can help us design teamwork better by working with this self-reliant tendency and letting employees reason privately before sharing advice that they might reject."

The study upends the belief that westerners work things out themselves while the rest of the world leans on others. In fact, intuition and self-reflection beat out advice from friends or crowdsourcing in all countries studied. The amount of that preference varied, depending on the level at which a culture values independence or interdependence.

"Our take-home message is that we all look inward first, yet the wisest moves may happen when solo reflections are shared with others," Grossmann said. "What culture does is controls the volume knob, dialing up that inner voice in highly independent societies and softening it somewhat in more interdependent ones."

Nearly 40 authors contributed to this work as part of the Geography of Philosophy Project, which is led by Dr. Edouard Machery, from the University of Pittsburgh.

The study, Decision-making preferences for intuition, deliberation, friends or crowds in independent and interdependent societies, appears in Proceedings of the Royal Society B Biological Sciences.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a significant international study revealing a shared human tendency toward self-reliance in decision-making across diverse cultures. This insight has broad implications for improving cross-cultural understanding and teamwork, offering a positive and inspiring perspective on human psychology and social behavior. The study is substantial, involving over 3,500 participants from 12 countries, and provides meaningful context and details.
articles.personality_title: Study finds people worldwide trust their own judgment when facing tough decisions
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – A large international study looked at how people from different cultures make difficult decisions. It included over 3,500 participants from 12 countries, ranging from big cities to remote Amazon communities.

**What happened** – Researchers from the University of Waterloo asked people how they decide on complex matters. They found that most people prefer to think things through on their own instead of asking others for advice. This was true across all cultures studied.

**Impact** – This challenges the old idea that only people in Western countries rely on themselves, while others depend on advice from friends or groups. The study showed that everyone tends to trust their own judgment first, although cultural values influence how strong this feeling is. Understanding this can help improve teamwork and reduce misunderstandings between cultures.

**What's next step** – Scientists hope this knowledge will help design better ways for people to work together. For example, allowing individuals time to think privately before sharing ideas might make group decisions stronger.

**One-sentence takeaway** – People around the world mostly trust their own thinking when making tough choices, regardless of culture.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une étude révèle que les gens du monde entier font confiance à leur propre jugement face aux décisions difficiles
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Une grande étude internationale a examiné comment les personnes de différentes cultures prennent des décisions difficiles. Elle a inclus plus de 3 500 participants de 12 pays, des grandes villes aux communautés reculées de l’Amazonie.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’Université de Waterloo ont demandé aux participants comment ils prennent des décisions complexes. Ils ont découvert que la plupart préfèrent réfléchir seuls plutôt que de demander conseil. Cela est vrai dans toutes les cultures étudiées.

**Impact** – Cela remet en question l’idée ancienne selon laquelle seules les personnes des pays occidentaux comptent sur elles-mêmes, tandis que d’autres s’appuient sur leurs amis ou groupes. L’étude montre que tout le monde fait d’abord confiance à son propre jugement, même si la culture influence cette tendance. Comprendre cela peut améliorer le travail en équipe et réduire les malentendus entre cultures.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques espèrent que cette connaissance aidera à mieux organiser le travail collectif. Par exemple, laisser du temps pour réfléchir seul avant de partager ses idées pourrait renforcer les décisions de groupe.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les gens du monde entier font surtout confiance à leur propre réflexion pour prendre des décisions difficiles, quelle que soit leur culture.
articles.personality_title_es: Un estudio revela que personas de todo el mundo confían en su propio juicio ante decisiones difíciles
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Un gran estudio internacional investigó cómo personas de diferentes culturas toman decisiones difíciles. Incluyó a más de 3,500 participantes de 12 países, desde grandes ciudades hasta comunidades remotas en la Amazonía.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad de Waterloo preguntaron a la gente cómo toman decisiones complejas. Descubrieron que la mayoría prefiere pensar por sí misma en lugar de pedir consejos. Esto fue cierto en todas las culturas estudiadas.

**Impacto** – Esto desafía la idea antigua de que solo las personas en países occidentales confían en sí mismas, mientras que otros dependen de amigos o grupos. El estudio mostró que todos tienden a confiar primero en su propio juicio, aunque los valores culturales influyen en qué tan fuerte es esta sensación. Entender esto puede ayudar a mejorar el trabajo en equipo y reducir malentendidos entre culturas.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos esperan que este conocimiento ayude a diseñar mejores formas para que las personas trabajen juntas. Por ejemplo, permitir que las personas piensen en privado antes de compartir ideas puede fortalecer las decisiones grupales.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Las personas en todo el mundo confían principalmente en su propio pensamiento al tomar decisiones difíciles, sin importar la cultura.
